    portfolio

    Human Resource Management Information System (HRMIS)

    Published: October 31, 2023

    The project focused on developing a functional system to manage employee data, with particular emphasis on attendance tracking. The system featured an Attendance class encapsulated within the Employee class, enabling efficient recording of employees’ in-time and out-time. It also included methods for calculating total working hours per day and displaying both individual and team attendance records.

    Product Design and Supply Chain Decisions Optimization

    Published: April 15, 2024

    This project aims to enhance the design and performance of complex products by jointly optimizing product design and supply chain decisions to maximize profit, improve customer satisfaction, and achieve operational efficiency while addressing the limitations of traditional sequential approaches.

    SWARM ROBOTICS IN UNDERWATER RESCUE MISSIONS USING THE EXTENDED PSO ALGORITHM (TAPSO)

    Published: April 29, 2024

    This research investigates the application of swarm robotics for underwater rescue operations through the development and implementation of a novel Task-Allocation Particle Swarm Optimization (TAPSO) algorithm. The study addresses the challenges of coordinating multiple autonomous underwater robots in complex three-dimensional environments, focusing on efficient target location and obstacle avoidance. Our enhanced PSO algorithm incorporates task allocation mechanisms to optimize the distribution of rescue responsibilities among swarm members.

    Deep Learning-Based Detection of Voice Deepfakes for Fraud Prevention

    Published: October 31, 2024

    This project focused on developing a deep learning model capable of distinguishing between real and artificially generated (deepfake) voice recordings. Using audio data from Hugging Face and Kaggle, the system applied consistent preprocessing steps—including resampling to 22,050 Hz and extracting Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs)—to ensure uniform input representation.

    People’s privacy concerns about new technology (focusing on LLMs)

    Published: November 29, 2024

    This study explored how people perceive and respond to privacy risks when using Large Language Models (LLMs). Through a survey of 25 participants, the research examined users’ knowledge levels, risk perceptions, and behavioral adaptations toward LLM privacy. The findings revealed a significant gap between perceived and actual privacy risks, with users who had lower privacy knowledge expressing higher concern levels.

    GAN-based Cross-Modality Medical Image Synthesis for Prostate Cancer

    Published: December 06, 2024

    This project presents a GAN-based approach for cross-modality medical image synthesis for prostate cancer diagnosis, using the BicycleGAN architecture to translate ADC MRI scans into high-quality T2-weighted (T2W) MRI images. The proposed method addresses the limitations of multi-sequence MRI acquisition by generating diagnostic-quality T2W images from ADC MRI scans, reducing the need for costly and time-intensive multi-sequence MRI image acquisition. Using a curated dataset of paired ADC and T2W MRI images, we trained the model and evaluated its performance using metrics including PSNR, SSIM, and L1 loss. Our results demonstrate that the enhanced model, incorporating self-attention mechanisms, perceptual loss, and gradient penalties, significantly improves structuralfidelity and pixel-wise accuracy. The model achieved a PSNR of 26.48 dB and L1 loss of 0.05 which is a considerable improvement from the baseline approach with PNSR of 25.57 dB and L1 loss of 0.39. This technique holds promise for streamlining prostate cancer diagnosis, particularly in low-resource settings, by reducing the need for multiple scans during diagnosis

    LLM-Assisted Hospital Navigation and Booking System

    Published: December 09, 2024

    This project aims to address the challenges patients face when navigating hospital websites, booking appointments, and accessing services hospital services. These difficulties often stem from complex interfaces which makes it difficult for patients to navigate hospital websites. To tackle this issue, a web-based intelligent chat-based navigation assistant prototype was developed. This system can provide natural language assistance for navigating services and booking appointments, connect to a mock hospital system API for real-time data on doctor availability, and implement a feedback mechanism for continuous improvement. Key features include seamless appointment booking without complex medical jargon, direct access to hospital information, efficient navigation to find relevant doctors and services, and real-time notifications for doctors about new appointments. The project, spanning six sprints, focused on information gathering, component development, system integration, backend development, testing, and deployment. The team created a minimum viable prototype to showcase the system’s capabilities and attract further investment for a comprehensive solution.

    Characterizing Sequential Patterns of Human Behavior in Advanced Manufacturing

    Published: June 01, 2025

    This project examined the temporal dynamics of human behavior in advanced manufacturing, focusing on interactions within a Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing (WAAM) system at Carnegie Mellon University. It explored whether human actions follow consistent sequential patterns, how these patterns vary across time scales, and what these variations reveal about cognitive and procedural structure in human-machine collaboration.

    Bridging the Communication Gap: Affordable Robotic Hands for Real-Time Sign Language Translation in Remote African Schools

    Published: July 14, 2025

    The project aims to address the severe shortage of sign language interpreters in African classrooms by developing a low-cost robotic system capable of translating between speech and sign language in real time. Designed to cost under $500, the system uses 3D-printed robotic hands to interpret spoken language into sign gestures and translate sign language back into text or speech. This approach offers a sustainable and scalable alternative to human interpreters, ensuring that deaf students in underserved regions can fully participate in classroom learning.

    publications

    Understanding the Impacts of Jointly Optimizing Product and Supply Chain Decisions for Complex Products

    Published in ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, 2024

    This paper examines how integrating product design and supply chain design decisions can improve outcomes for complex products, using a ground vehicle as a case study.

    Recommended citation: Uhles, C., Mudzurandende, M., McComb, C., & Medal, H. (2024). "Understanding the Impacts of Jointly Optimizing Product and Supply Chain Decisions for Complex Products." ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, 88599, V001T02A016.
    Download Paper

    Characterizing Sequential Patterns of Human Behavior in Advanced Manufacturing

    Published in Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering (JCISE), Submitted, 2025

    This paper investigates sequential patterns of human behavior in advanced manufacturing environments, highlighting insights for process optimization and safety.

    Recommended citation: Mudzurandende, M., Flanigan, K., & McComb, C. (2025). "Characterizing Sequential Patterns of Human Behavior in Advanced Manufacturing." Journal of Computing and Information Science in Engineering (JCISE). Submitted.

    talks

    teaching

    Applied Stochastic Processes

    Graduate course, Carnegie Mellon University, 2024

    As a Teaching Assistant for Applied Stochastic Processes, I supported the course by preparing instructional materials and clarifying complex concepts for students. I provided individualized assistance during office hours and recitations, fostering student engagement and understanding of stochastic modeling techniques. I also graded assignments and maintained accurate records of student progress to ensure effective course management.

    Humanoid Robotics and Cognition

    Graduate Course, Carnegie Mellon University, 2025

    As a Teaching Assistant for Humanoid Robotics and Cognition, I helped students navigate hands-on robotics experiments and understand how sensors, control systems, and AI come together. I offered guidance during labs and office hours, answering questions and supporting students as they explored complex concepts. I also reviewed lab reports and tracked student progress to help the course run smoothly.

    Privacy Policy, Law and Technology

    Graduate Course, Carnegie Mellon University, 2025

    As a Teaching Assistant for Privacy Policy, Law, and Technology, I guided students through complex discussions on data privacy, ethical considerations, and legal frameworks in technology. I supported learning by answering questions, clarifying concepts, and facilitating engagement during seminars and office hours. I also helped review assignments and track student progress to ensure the course ran smoothly.
